data.title: Classic film review: The Impossible Voyage by Georges Méliès
data.meta_description: Stop me if you’ve heard this before. A director makes a film about a lunar expedition that sparks an intergalactic war. Featuring knockout special effects, the film is fast, funny and exciting and an enormous hit, breaking box-office records and winning five-star reviews around the world. Inevitably
data.text:
Stop me if you’ve heard this before. A director makes a film about a lunar expedition that sparks an intergalactic war. Featuring knockout special effects, the film is fast, funny and exciting and an enormous hit, breaking box-office records and winning five-star reviews around the world. Inevitably the director turns his attention to a sequel, about an equally perilous trip to the sun, that’s even more lavish. Although critics complain — too many effects, not enough story and so many holes in the science you could pilot a rocket ship through them — the film becomes one of the most popular of the new century.

So much for Georges Méliès’s The Impossible Voyage (1904), filmed a few years after his groundbreaking A Trip to the
